title: Large Language Models Predict Cognition and Education Close to or Better than Genomics or Expert Assessment

authors.name: Felix C. Tropf
affiliations: Centre de Recherche en Économie et Statistique
École Nationale de la Statistique et de l'Administration Économique

abstract: Previous research using standard social survey data has emphasized a relative lack of power when predicting educational and psychological outcomes. Leveraging a unique longitudinal dataset, we explore the potential predictive ceilings for educational attainment, cognitive abilities, and non-cognitive traits using recent advances in deep learning-based natural language processing, the frontier of genomic techniques, and teacher-based assessment. We show that short aspirational essays of around 250 words written at age 11 accurately predict cognition and non-cognitive traits at the same and later age, similar to teacher assessment. The same is true for predicting final educational attainment. Genomic prediction is substantially less accurate. When these three non-standard measures are combined into an ensemble model, they can nearly perfectly predict cognitive ability (70%, close to test-retest reliability) and explain 38% of individual differences in educational attainment. These findings show that recent advances in large language modeling equip behavioral and social scientists with tools for accurate prediction, strongly motivating responsible research into a deeper understanding of the information which such models are accurately able to contextualise.

Large Language Models Predict Cognition and Education Close to or1
Better than Genomics or Expert Assessment2
Tobias Wolfram1, Felix C. Tropf2,3, and Charles Rahal4
3
1Faculty of Sociology, Bielefeld University, Germany4
2Centre for Longitudinal Studies, Social Research Institute, University College London, UK5
3Department of Sociology, Purdue University, USA6
4Leverhulme Centre for Demographic Science and Nuffield College, University of Oxford, UK7
December 14, 20248
Abstract9
Previous research using standard social survey data has emphasized a relative lack of power10
when predicting educational and psychological outcomes. Leveraging a unique longitudinal dataset,11
we explore predictability of educational attainment, cognitive abilities, and non-cognitive traits. In-12
tegrating various measures of computational linguistics and large language model-based embeddings13
within a SuperLearner framework trained on short aspirational essays written at age 11, we accu-14
rately predict cognition and non-cognitive traits at the same and later age to a similar degree as15
teacher assessments, and substantially better than genomic data. The same is true for predicting final16
educational attainment. Combining text, genetic markers, and teacher assessments into an ensemble17
model, we can nearly perfectly predict cognitive ability (70%, close to test-retest reliability) and18
explain 38% of individual differences in attainment. A relatively standard sociological model which19
is equivalent to the baseline of the Fragile Family Challenge is able to replicate their relatively low20
accuracy. These findings show that recent advances in large language models and machine learning21
equip behavioural scientists with tools for accurate prediction of psycho-social features.22
Keywords: Psychological Methods, Longitudinal Surveys, Machine Learning23
Data Availability: All non-genetic data associated with the project can be downloaded from the website of the UK Data
Service, organized in sets of .dta files, a joint one for Sweep 0-3 and additional ones for each subsequent wave. Essays are
accessible separately. Access to genetic data requires a separate application to the data access committee of the Center for
Longitudinal Studies (CLS) and was obtained by the authors under application GDAC-2021-13-TROPF. Our embeddings are
available upon request for the purposes of replication to accredited parties who have fulfilled all necessary compliance related
steps. Code Availability: All statistical software used for generating the results in this paper are currently hosted in a private
GitHub repository. We have made our code available anonymously on the anonymous.4open.science/ platform for full review under
the URL anonymous.4open.science/r/mmg_paper-F840. The code will be made publicly available following the article’s acceptance
for publication. Prior Dissemination: This manuscript has been presented at the Social Science Genetics Network Conference
2022 in Bologna and at the International Society for Intelligence Research Conference 2023 in Berkeley. A preprint is available
at https://osf.io/preprints/socarxiv/a8ht9. Acknowledgements: F.C.T. was supported by the Laboratory of Excellence in
Economics and Decision Sciences (LabEx Ecodec) funded under the French National Research Agency (ANR) Investissements
d’Avenir (Grant ANR-11-LABX-0047) and the UKRI project FINDME (EP/Y023080/1). C.R. is grateful for support from the
Leverhulme Trust (Grant RC-2018-003) for the Leverhulme Centre for Demographic Science, and Nuffield College. The authors
declare no competing interests. Correspondence: Correspondence concerning this article should be addressed to Tobias Wolfram,
Faculty of Sociology, Bielefeld University, Universit¨ atsstraße 25, 33615 Bielefeld, Germany. Email: tobias.wolfram@uni-bielefeld.de.
1
1 Introduction24
Psychological, life-course, and behavioural prediction is an increasingly recognized and timely goal (Berk25
et al., 2019; Chandler et al., 2011; Cranmer and Desmarais, 2017; Hofman et al., 2021; Kleinberg et al.,26
2015; Watts, 2014; Yarkoni and Westfall, 2017). One driving motivation is to identify individuals at27
risk for negative outcomes and inform the timing and type of intervention, with earlier work focusing28
on specific outcomes such as the onset of mental health problems (Tate et al., 2020). A recent study29
(Salganik et al., 2020) – the ‘Fragile Families Challenge’ (FFC) – utilised the ‘common task method’30
(Donoho, 2017), concluding with a somewhat pessimistic outlook. One hundred and sixty research groups31
leveraged 12,942 social survey variables from the Future of Families and Child Wellbeing Study (FFCWS),32
making available recent advances in computational power and machine learning algorithms which are33
increasingly popularised in the social sciences (Rahal et al., 2021). The most successful predictions34
explained only approximately 20% of individual differences in Grade Point Average (GPA) and Material35
Hardship (out-of-sample). For non-cognitive traits such as ‘grit’, the accuracy was as low as 5%.36
However, there are methodological developments that promise improvements in predictions too. The37
revolution in natural language processing (NLP) using deep learning techniques – such as transformer-38
based language models (Vaswani et al., 2017) – has sparked an extraordinary advancement in the way39
machines can interact with humans and generate human-like language (Brown et al., 2020). These40
developments have not only led to the widespread adoption of NLP in a variety of real-world applications,41
including ‘chatbots’, virtual assistants, and automated customer service systems (Dale, 2021), but have42
also opened up a vast array of new research opportunities. Attention is gradually turning towards more43
generalisable problems with frontier technologies (such as the ‘predictability hypotheses’ as outlined by44
van Loon, 2023), such as analysing dense data on life-events within vector spaces which represent human45
life courses. In some domains, epistemic error is being rapidly eliminated in a way which reduces total46
predictive error to its purely aleatoric component (for a generalised framework, see Yan and Rahal, 2024).47
It has, for example, been shown that it is feasible to operationalise life courses through a comprehensive48
registrar of individual, micro-level data which are readable as language and are amenable to NLP-49
based predictions (Savcisens et al., 2023). Here, we explore the extent to which NLP can help to50
predict a key part of the educational and psycho-social life course based on alternative, non-standard51
data sources. We exploit information from aspirational essays written by children at the formative age52
of eleven, and we compare predictions made from them with state-of-the-art genomic techniques and53
teacher assessments. With this non-standard data, we are able to contrast our accurate predictions with54
studies such as Salganik et al. (2020) and Lundberg et al. (2024), which claim that human lives are55
essentially ‘unpredictable’. This is made possible by a unique birth cohort based study which allows56
such an expansive research design.57
Previous text-based attempts have achieved only limited success in predicting, for example, person-58
ality, mental health, cognitive ability, and educational achievement, with variance explanations ranging59
from 5-10% (Abramov and Yampolskiy, 2019; C¨ oltekin, 2020; Fast and Funder, 2008; Rodriguez et al.,60
2010). However – in an approach not dissimilar to Jones (2013a) – Alvero et al. (2021) recently demon-61
strated the potential of essay content and style in predicting authors’ outcomes. Using 240,000 admission62
essays submitted by 60,000 applicants to the University of California, they applied Linguistic Inquiry63
and Word Count (LIWC) as well as Correlated Topic Modeling (CTM) to ∼1,400 words per respondent,64
resulting in benchmarks of up to 49% variance explained in a composite SAT score and 16% for house-65
hold income. Such findings suggest that prediction might be possible based on information hidden in66
alternative data sources in comparison to standard classical survey data.67
The sample used in Alvero et al. (2021) was highly selective and homogenous, comprising only68
potential college students, which restricts generalizability. SAT scores and household income represent a69
specific yet limited set of traits that may be highly correlated with textual data. Such findings strongly70
motivate further research on the potential of text-based prediction,in order to define both the reducible71
and irreducible ‘origins of unpredictability’ (Lundberg et al., 2024). We aim to identify how accurate72
these computationally advanced text-based predictions are for a wider range of psycho-social outcomes73
– educational attainment and cognitive traits and non-cognitive traits – utilizing recent advances in74
natural language processing techniques (e.g. Brown et al., 2020). Our research design allows us to surpass75
previously understood accuracy as reached in the existing literature. It does this by utilizing state-of-the-76
art algorithms and computational approaches resulting in combining more than 500 lexicographic metrics77
used in computational linguistics with high-dimensional, deep-learning-based numerical representations78
of each text sample. Importantly, our analyses focus on small text samples of around∼250 words only. To79
maximize predictive accuracy, we use these extracted features as input to an array of established machine80

learning algorithms within an ensemble SuperLearner framework (Polley and Van Der Laan, 2010; Van81
der Laan et al., 2007). Through extensive, repeated algorithic training and testing in subsamples of our82
data via the process of cross-validation, we arrive at a substantial predictive accuracy on held-out test83
data while also protecting against over-fitting.84
We examine predictions across various outcomes and time spans, from contemporaneous outcomes85
such as cognitive abilities at age 11 – when the text samples are collected – to those decades later such as86
educational attainment of the children at age 33. We are motivated to study educational attainment as87
this can be considered the central stratum in the contemporary world (Becker, 1964; Blau and Duncan,88
1967) and is highly consequential for multiple channels of life course trajectories (Clark and Royer,89
2013; Filippova et al., 2019; Zajacova and Lawrence, 2018). However, the causal effect of educational90
attainment on individuals’ life courses has also been challenged, highlighting the possibility that it is91
mainly a proxy for effects of educational precursors such as cognitive ability and non-cognitive traits92
(Caplan, 2019). Therefore, we include these psychological life course predictors in our study. We contrast93
and combine our text-based prediction with teacher assessments of students and state-of-the-art genomic94
prediction of multiple polygenic scores (see Section 4). Teacher assessments represent the most common95
alternative to academic tracking for career prediction (Baeriswyl et al., 2011) and show moderate to high96
correlations with traits such as academic achievement (r = 0.65) and cognitive ability (r = 0.5, Urhahne97
and Wijnia, 2021). These are the current limits to predictive accuracy given our existent understanding98
of the literature. Investigating the accuracy of prediction with these outcomes is, in general, of great99
interest to recent meta-theoretical considerations. The comparison and combination of human judgment100
and machine-based predictions has gained substantial interest not only for macro-economic or political101
trends, but primarily for individual outcomes such as health diagnostics (Zellner et al., 2021), despite only102
occasional use in the social sciences (Filippova et al., 2019). Note that in our comparisons, we also rebuilt103
the predictive sociological model from the FFC in an analogy between GPA and educational attainment,104
nearly perfectly replicating their results in our data despite the slight measurement difference.105
There are also longstanding questions regarding the role of genetics and the (social) environment,106
which can be answered by considering the interplay of information generated at differential parts of an107
individual’s life (Dick, 2011). Our work speaks to the ‘gloomy prospective’ of Plomin and others (Plomin108
and Daniels, 1987) where it is claimed that only genetic variation (and its phenotypical proxies) are useful109
for prediction (Plomin, 2011) and – controversially – should be used as information for college admission110
(Plomin, 2018). We believe that we are the first to engage in a direct comparison of state-of-the-art111
genetic prediction – common in science and society (Hart, 2016; Morris et al., 2020; Plomin, 2018) – with112
teacher assessment and essay-based predictions. The ‘gloomy prospect’ of unpredictability exemplifies a113
meta-theoretical framework that hypothesizes the complexity-driven unpredictability of historical events,114
testable through prediction algorithms rather than traditional inferential methods (Risi et al., 2019; van115
Loon, 2023).116
3
The National Child Development Study (NCDS, Power and Elliott, 2006) provides us with a unique117
opportunity, allowing us to compare cutting edge approaches to prediction in a comparative setting. This118
British birth cohort data collection – which started in 1958 – is still ongoing. It requested participants119
at age eleven to write an essay of roughly 250-word length under the theme of “Imagine you are 25”120
(see Section 4.1.1). At the same age, teachers of the respondents were asked to assess their students’121
general knowledge, number work, use of books, and oral ability – all on a scale from one to five – as well122
as certain behaviors and motor abilities on a scale from one to three (see Section 4.1.2). Eventually, in123
2002, blood samples of participants were collected and later genotyped (see Section 4.1.3). Importantly124
for our research design and the practical goals of behavioral and life course prediction more broadly –125
e.g. intervention (Hart, 2016) – our measures are time-invariant early-life course predictors, with the126
genome fixed at conception.127
Similar to our text-based analysis, genomics confronts us with the challenge of large, seldom unstruc-128
tured data. Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) link molecular genetic variations to psychological129
and social outcomes (Lee et al., 2018) and allow out-of-sample prediction from genotyped data based130
on individual genetic summary scores (Selzam et al., 2017; von Stumm et al., 2020). We follow this131
approach to reduce the complexity of 35 million genetic markers by applying standard quality control132
and merging with publicly available summary statistics from highly powered GWAS. We apply a multi-133
polygenic score (PGS) approach to trait prediction (see Section 4) leveraging a set of 33 traits which134
theory would suggest are associated with our outcomes of interest (Krapohl et al., 2018). Our overall135
research design is schematically displayed in Figure 1, where we also additionally highlight the temporal136
element to our predictions.137
2 Results138
2.1 Essays, Teacher Assessments and Genetic Markers Predict Cognitive139
and Non-Cognitive Traits140
We denote predictive power using R2
Holdout scores, where 0 equals the performance of a prediction based141
on the training-sample mean, and 1 is a perfect prediction, roughly comparable to the well-known and142
more traditional in-sample R2; see Section 4, Material and Methods for details regarding our approach143
and our supplementary material for full details. With this metric, the performance of natural language144
processing (NLP) based information sets from essays for cognitive abilities and non-cognitive traits is145
substantial, and approaches or exceeds teacher assessments (TA, see Figure 2). Predictions are strongest146
for reading (at age 11, NLP = 0.59; TA = 0.57; at age 16 NLP = 0.58; TA = 0.56), verbal (0.55; 0.57),147
mathematical (at age 11, 0.55; 0.57; at age 16, 0.55; 0.62) abilities and smaller for non-verbal ability148
(0.37; 0.45). Genetic predictions are substantially smaller, with 0.14, 0.15, 0.13, 0.16, 0.17, and 0.11 for149
reading, verbal, mathematical, and non-verbal ability. The prediction for non-cognitive traits is much150
less precise in general. For occupational aspiration, essays have of R2
Holdout of, TA 0.11, and PGSs of 0.04.151
The pattern is similar for scholastic motivation (0.08; 0.09; 0.05) whilst externalizing shows a moderate152
prediction based on TA (0.08; 0.19; 0.04) and internalizing behavior is least predictable (0.03, 0.08, and153
0.01). Additionally, we found that our models could predict ‘Big 5’ personality traits measured at age154
50, with essays predicting over 10% of the variance in agreeableness and openness (see Supplementary155
Section C.2 and Supplementary Figure D.10). 1156
2.2 Embeddings drive Performance of Textual Prediction157
We aim to understand the efficacy of our textual prediction model by decomposing our SuperLearner(s)158
into a series of discrete submodels. These submodels consisted of: a) Traditional readability metrics, b)159
Orthographic and grammatical error ratios, c) Advanced computational linguistic measures, including160
1As outlined in Section 4, we used L1 regularization to pre-screen variables in each fold of the SuperLearner. We examined
the consistency of feature selection across all folds and outcome variables for each of the three basic SuperLearner models.
For the genetic model, all polygenic scores were selected at least once, with household income, educational attainment, and
age at first birth being the most consistently selected. In the teacher evaluation model, all covariates were also selected at
least once, with general knowledge, number work, and oral ability assessments being selected in every instance. For the

by embedding dimensions (87) derived from the large language model. Only two non-embedding features from the essays
are found among the top 10 most consistently selected: The root type-token ratio and the measure of textual lexical
diversity (MTLD), with the former being selected in 96.6% of all models.

2.4 Essays, Teacher Assessments, and PGSs Predict Educational Attainment184
comparably to Cognitive Skills and Non-Cognitive Traits185
The joint overall SuperLearner prediction with a model built on each of the three main data sources186
(TA, NLP, PGS) for educational attainment at age 33 is 0.38, far superseding linear models based on187
cognitive ability, as well as non-cognitive traits (Fig. 5). That analysis also includes birth weight and188
height as two popular biological predictors of education for comparison. However, those measures only189
predict attained education by accuracies of 0.01 and 0.03 respectively. To put the performance of our190
models into context, one of the most heralded sociological predictors of educational attainment – parental191
education – is only able predict with an accuracy of 0.12. Importantly, we rebuild an extended version192
of the sociological model from the FFC to predict educational attainment – in parallel to their outcome193
measure of GPA – based on the child’s sex at birth, father’s education level, mother’s education level,194
social class of the mother’s husband, household living density (persons per room), father’s socioeconomic195
classification and social class of the mother’s father. These results from our more sociological model act196
as a vaguely proximal replication of that earlier work, with an R 2
Holdout of 0.18 in a generealised linear197
framework (0.19 with a SuperLearner).198

3 Discussion199
We utilise recent and substantial developments in NLP to re-estimate how accurate social and psycho-200
social prediction can be based on the extent to which small amounts of text can predict the cognitive201
skills, non-cognitive traits, and educational attainment of individuals. Our study shows – in contrast202
to previous claims (Plomin and Daniels, 1987; Salganik et al., 2020; Turkheimer, 2000) – that moderate203
to highly accurate predictions of such outcomes are possible. Predictions for educational attainment204
nearly double the predictive accuracy seen in the more temporally proximal measured Grade Point205
Average or Material Hardship of the FFC. Our text-based predictions reach an accuracy of 0.56 based206
on a substantially shorter essay ( ∼250 words) and in a smaller, yet much more representative sample207
than the most closely related existing research which leverages textual data (Alvero et al., 2021). The208
prediction of our best model approaches test-retest reliability of benchmark intelligence tests (Canivez209
and Watkins, 1998). While our predictions for non-cognitive traits still exceed the benchmark predictions210
for ‘grit’ in the FFC, these traits appear to be less easily predicted than cognition and education based on211
our data and methodology. The FFC provided participants with information on both test scores and a212
teacher survey; one of our main predictors. Heterogeneity in prediction success can therefore have other213
sources, too, such as sample selection, the exact intricacies of the measurement of outcomes of interest,214
and the homogeneity of participants natural to the birth cohort study which we use in contrast to other215
data sources.216
Accurate predictions of psychological and social outcomes are highly relevant to various current217
debates. While survey data might be limited in its ability to provide precise predictions, and our218
study shows the opportunities available from alternative data, and in the process identifies space for219
positive intervention. Our approach offers a fresh perspective on this ‘gloomy prospect’ (Lundberg220
et al., 2024; Plomin and Daniels, 1987) of unpredictablity. Additionally, the juxtaposition of “man”221
against “machine” has a long tradition (Jones, 2013b), and we show how progress in the field produces222
reasonable essay assessments as a function of NLP algorythms (Feigenbaum and Gross, 2020). In this223
sense, AI-based automation of teaching tasks is a potential challenge in current debates on technology224
and education (Selwyn, 2021), with growing interest dedicated to the task of automating essay scoring225
(Foltz et al., 2020). Will algorithms such as those developed within this paper one day replace the role226
of teachers’ assessments, or help to re-frame the debate around alternative sources of admissions data?227
We show that – based on the current state-of-the-art technologies – teachers’ assessments still provide228
strong predictive accuracy, and we subsequently stress the importance of expert opinion at a time when229
8
some look to automation. However, given that textual samples were able to provide an almost equivalent230
predictive power to the teacher-evaluation-based predictions, there is clear evidence that machines can231
support teacher’s work in schools too, with further methodological development surely forthcoming in232
this area.233
In the past, textual data has been of rather limited utility to quantitative and computational re-234
searchers. While our approach presents an example of how information encoded within complex data235
resources can be realised to create societal value, it also puts into perspective the use of prediction based236
on genetics for collegiate admissions (Plomin, 2018) in comparison to other sources of complex informa-237
tion, although we acknowledge the potential to further improve in the future in conjunction with ever238
more powerful genetic discoveries (Wainschtein et al., 2022). It must also be emphasized that our results239
should be contextualised within a specific place, space and time. We also note the cost – in terms of240
both data collection and computational processing – of working with textual and genomic data. For that241
reason, in limited resource settings, we show and emphasize here the value that remains in the use of242
teacher assessments; they perform well, and are otherwise relatively inexpensive to collect and process.243
As alluded to in Section 1, this work is only possible because of the design of one specific and unique244
dataset, which by definition prohibits exploration of external validity. While showing substantial promise245
with respect to its predictive performance and a clear need for the increased collection of non-standard246
data such as this (the expense of doing so not withstanding), our work also raises important ethical247
questions, as it will almost certainly be the case that predictive accuracy continues to increase across248
and be integrated into all aspects of society. Confidence in applied predictive systems has led to mistakes249
in the past, not least in the fields of recidivism (Chouldechova, 2017) and credit default (Fuster et al.,250
2022). Bias in educational testing also has a storied history, anticipating many aspects of the modern251
algorithmic bias and fairness literature (Baker and Hawn, 2021), and is none more important than within252
the era of large language models. As digital measures are slowly emerging, identifying the appropriate253
regulation of increasingly accurate applications of (social and behavioural) prediction remains a key254
consideration for further ethical research.255
3.1 Limitations256
Although we demonstrate the predictability of psycho-social outcomes, our study is not withouth limi-257
tations. First, it is unclear to what extent our results are generalizable as they are based on a particular258
sample of individuals born in the year 1958 in Great Britain, and their educational biographies might259
not be comparable to that of today’s contemporary pupils within or outside of the UK. This underscores260
the need for more longitudinal datasets which combine different and diverse types of non-standard data261
with classical social surveys and behavioral assessments. In our supplementary information (Section C),262
we address potential concerns related to variations in sample composition due to different non-response263
patterns across different variables. Specifically, we reran our primary analyses on a subset of 1,618 indi-264
viduals with full information across all key variables. Although predictive performance showed increased265
variation in this reduced sample, our findings remained robust. Despite these robustness checks, we266
acknowledge the potential influence of systematic missingness – especially in the genetic subsample – on267
our results.268
Second, prediction alone is not sufficient to understand the factors that drive the association be-269
tween non-standard data sources and outcomes, and future research should investigate the mechanisms270
connecting the information in the essays with the successful prediction of the outcomes.271
Finally, we have not data mined the three sources of information as thoroughly as we might have272
done, or utilised more emergent GPT models. An example of this is the fact that we created PGS273
using Clumping and Thresholding with a prespecified p-value threshold of 0.5 and we want to make our274
applications as standardised as possible; custom thresholds per trait would likely increase the predictive275
accuracy of our models even further. The same holds for more sophisticated Bayesian methods of PGS276
construction that leverage functional information about the genome (Zheng et al., 2024), which may277
further increase predictive performance, though likely not qualitatively change results. Similarly – and278
while we found no discernible difference between the models which we employed – Large Language Models279
are currently evolving rapidly, and analysis done on closed models is subject to change at the behest of280
those who release their trained models. See Section 4 for additional information on the variations we281
have explored in general.282
9
4 Methods283
4.1 Data284
The dataset used for our analyses is the National Child Development Study (NCDS), an ongoing British285
birth cohort study starting with 17,415 children born in a single week of 1958. We seek to evaluate the286
extent to which genomic data, teacher assessments, and the information embedded in the essays are able287
to predict outcome variables that can be broadly categorized under three different themes: cognitive288
abilities, non-cognitive traits, and socioeconomic outcomes, most of which are directly taken from the289
NCDS data or created using factor analysis. We briefly describe the construction of all variables involved290
and refer to the Supplementary Information for a detailed discussion.291
4.1.1 Essays292
At age eleven, study participants were asked to write an essay under the theme “Imagine you are 25”. In293
total 10,511 essays of varying lengths (ranging from 1 to 1239 words) were transcribed. We apply various294
approaches to extract the maximum amount of information from them. First, by using a pre-trained and295
state-of-the-art deep-learning NLP model – text-embedding-ada-002 – to extract representations of296
the words of all essays in lower dimensional space. These embeddings capture the semantic importance297
of each word in context and allow the expression of the texts by numeric vectors along 1,536 dimensions.298
In addition, we measure 535 linguistic metrics of lexical diversity (TAALED, Kyle et al., 2021), lexical299
sophistication (TAALES, Kyle et al., 2018) and sentiment (SEANCE, Crossley et al., 2017), 31 metrics of300
readability, and grammatical and typographical error/word-ratios. Additional details on the construction301
of these features is provided in Supplementary Information Section A.1.302
4.1.2 Teacher Evaluations303
We use 22 teacher-related variables overall. At age eleven, teachers of the respondents were asked to304
assess their students’ general knowledge, number work, use of books, oral ability on a scale from one to305
five, as well as certain behaviors and motor abilities on a scale from one to three. In addition, a series of306
behavioral descriptions were given to a teacher who is asked to underline the descriptions which best fit307
the child. By summing the number of selected items, a quantitative assessment of the child’s adjustment308
to school is obtained for multiple categories of behavior. Additional details on the construction of these309
features are provided in Supplementary Information Section A.2.310
4.1.3 Genomic Data311
We utilize genotyped data from multiple subsets of NCDS participants. We combine all available genomic312
data into a single file and restricted the available single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to those in313
common with the reference panel of the 1000 Genomes Project. The final sample contains 37,772,588314
variants across 6,437 individuals. Using PRSice2 (Choi and O’Reilly, 2019), we then utilized publicly315
available summary statistics of genome-wide association studies to construct polygenic scores for a set of316
33 curated traits (listed in Table E.1) 3. These summary statistics span the realms of cognition, mental317
health, personality, physical composure, social behavior, and substance abuse. Additional details on the318
construction of these features are provided in Supplementary Information Section A.3. All polygenic319
scores were jointly used as input to the SuperLearner (see below), akin to a multi-polygenic score model320
(Krapohl et al., 2018). Given our focus on predictive power rather than causal inference, we did not321
correct for population stratification, as doing so could potentially reduce the predictive utility of the322
polygenic scores in our specific population. This follows the argument outlined by Plomin and Von Stumm323
(2022), which considers population stratification as a valid source of genetic variance for polygenic score324
prediction within a defined population.325
4.2 Analytical Strategy326
We run the SuperLearner with nested cross-validation, using 5-folds in the inner and 10 in the outer327
loop. We utilise the Mean Squared Error as the cost function using the SuperLearner package in R. No328
3As an exploratory robustness check, the extensive set of polygenic scores provided by the Polygenic Index Repository
Becker et al. (2021) constructed using LDPred (Priv´ e et al., 2020) was also tested in preliminary analyses as a comparision,
leading to qualitatively similar results, see Figure D.1. In all but one example (Internalizing Behavior at Age 16), the
PGI-Repository scores generated less accurate predictions.
10
preregistration of our analysis took place.329
4.2.1 Metrics used330
As detailed in our supplementary appendix, we employed several approaches to extract information from331
the essays:332
• GPT-based embeddings using thetext-embedding-ada-002 model resulting in a 1,536-dimensional333
vector for each essay.334
• SALAT-metrics, providing 534 measures related to various linguistic aspects.335
• Readability-metrics, consisting of 31 different measures from the koRpus-package.336
• Grammatical and typographical error ratios, derived using the LanguageTool CLI.337
Despite the fact that the main aspects of our analysis were conducted using GPT-3.5, we also compare338
our results to RoBERTa and GPT 4.0 embeddings. The results – shown in Figure D.2 – are largely339
invariant across the GPT 3.5 and 4.0 embeddings, but both offer predictive gains above the RoBERTa340
embeddings.341
4.2.2 Size of predictive models342
Our main predictive model – as shown in Figure 2 – incorporates all above different types of text-based343
features in the SuperLearner framework. The model is large and comprehensive, and as detailed above,344
uses four key types of extracted information. In Figure 4, we demonstrate the incremental utility of each345
individual information set in comparison to other commonly utilised – and simpler – alternatives.346
4.2.3 SuperLearner347
To reduce learning error as much as is reasonably possible with input data from across from the three in-348
formation sources (teacher assessments, essays, genomic data), we utilise a SuperLearner-based approach349
(Polley and Van Der Laan, 2010; Van der Laan et al., 2007). SuperLearners are ensemble algorithms350
that estimate the performance of a selection of machine learning models based on cross-validation. The351
SuperLearner algorithm combines predictions from multiple individual machine learning models, such as352
Extreme Gradient Boosting, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machines, all in order to generate a fi-353
nal prediction. This is done through a process called ‘stacking’ or ‘model averaging’. We used the default354
settings provided by the SuperLearner package in R for each algorithm, without performing additional355
algorithm-specific hyper-parameter tuning. This approach focused on the overall ensemble performance356
while maintaining computational efficiency and reducing overfitting risks. As a large number of vari-357
ables are extracted from the essays in the form of word embeddings and beyond, LASSO regressions358
(implemented in glmnet) are used as a pre-screening algorithm. LASSO pre-processing was performed359
once per outcome per fold in the cross-validation process. We use a diverse range of state-of-the-art360
machine-learning models as inputs to the SuperLearner: Extreme Gradient Boosting, as implemented in361
the package xgboost (Chen et al., 2015), RandomForest, as implemented in the package ranger (Wright362
and Ziegler, 2015), a shallow neural network as implemented in the package nnet, SVM with a Radial363
Basis Kernel as implemented in the package ksvm, a simple linear regression model in base R, and the364
mean of the outcome in the training set. From these estimates, the SuperLearner determines an optimal365
weighted average prediction based on the performance of individual composite models. The weights366
attributed to each of these individual models can be seen in Figure D.3, which indicates that it is the367
Linear Model and the Random Forest which receive the highest weightings across almost all outcomes.368
4.2.4 Cross-validation369
For each outcome variable in each fold, a separate LASSO model was fit to select relevant features. We370
used 10-fold cross-validation for all three of our types of models (textual data, genomic data, and teacher371
assessments). However – as we document in detail in the supplementary material – the performance372
of a linear model was comparable for genomic data and teacher assessments. The textual data, on the373
other hand, benefited significantly from the SuperLearner approach, which is why we emphasize the374
cross-validated results for this model. The number of features retained varied depending on the outcome375
variable and specific fold.376
11
4.2.5 Metric assessment377
We use the R2
Holdout metric, also known as the ‘predictive R 2’, as our primary evaluation criterion. This378
choice aligns with recent related studies in the literature (Salganik et al., 2020). The R 2
Holdout can be379
considered a predictive counterpart to the well-known coefficient of determination (R 2). This metric380
assesses a model’s predictive performance by comparing its predictions on holdout data to a baseline381
prediction using only the mean of the training set. Specifically, for each cross-validation fold, we calculate:382
R2
Holdout = 1 −
P
i∈Holdout(yi − ˆyi)2
P
i∈Holdout(yi − ¯yTraining)2
where yi is the actual value for observation i in the holdout set ˆyi is the predicted value for observation383
i ¯yTraining is the mean of the target variable in the training set. The interpretation of R 2
Holdout – while384
similar in some respects to the standard in-sample R 2 – has important differences. A value of 1 still385
indicates perfect prediction. A value of 0 suggests the model’s predictions on the holdout set are no386
better than simply using the training set mean (or prevalence in the case of binary dependent variables).387
Negative values are possible in contrast to standard R 2, indicating that the model’s predictions on new388
data are worse than using the training set mean. Unlike the standard R 2 – which is always between 0389
and 1 for models with an intercept – the R 2
Holdout can take on any value less than or equal to 1 (i.e., be390
infinitely negative in the case of infinitely inaccurate predictions). This reflects its nature as a measure of391
out-of-sample predictive performance, rather than in-sample fit. The R 2
Holdout provides a more realistic392
assessment of a model’s predictive capability on new, unseen data, making it particularly useful for393
evaluating and comparing predictive models. 4394
4It’s worth noting that our implementation – which uses cross-validation – technically results in what Bates et al. (2023)
refer to as R 2
CV. While R 2
Holdout and R2
CV are conceptually similar in that they both assess out-of-sample performance,
they have slightly different estimands. R 2
CV provides an estimate of expected performance on a new sample from the
same population, while R 2
Holdout estimates performance on a specific held-out dataset. While we use the term R 2
Holdout
throughout this paper for consistency with previous literature in our field, we take this chance to acknowledge the technical
distinction between R2
Holdout and R2
CV here.

A Feature Engineering564
A.1 Essays565
At age 11, study participants were asked to write an essay whilst being observed by their teachers. The566
theme of the essay was set as “Imagine you are 25”. The exact set of instructions given were as follows:567
“Imagine you are now 25 years old. Write about the life you are leading, your interests, your568
home life and your work at the age of 25. You have 30 minutes to do this.”569
In total, 10,511 essays of varying length – ranging from 1 to 1,239 words – were transcribed. See Figure570
D.4 for a visualisation of the distribution of essay lengths. We apply various approaches which extract571
the maximal amount of information from these essays:572
• GPT-based embeddings: We utilize the text-embedding-ada-002 model, a pre-trained and573
state-of-the-art deep learning natural language processing (NLP) model provided via the OpenAI-574
Platform API, to generate vector representations of the words in all essays. This model converts575
each essay into a 1,536-dimensional numeric vector, capturing the semantic meaning of words in576
their context. These embeddings provide a lower-dimensional representation of the text that pre-577
serves important semantic information, allowing for efficient computational analysis of the essays’578
content using our SuperLearner pipeline.579
• SALAT-metrics: The Suite of Automatic Linguistic Analysis Tools (SALAT) is a set of open-580
source linguistic programs. We use it to derive 814 measures related to lexical sophistication, text581
cohesion, syntactic complexity, lexical diversity, grammar and sentiment for each essay. Keeping582
only those metrics that are available for all texts, we end up with 534 measures in total.583
• Readability-metrics: Readability metrics measure the ease with which a reader can understand584
a written text based on its number of words, sentences, characters, and syllables. The koRpus-585
package provides a set of 31 of such metrics (ARI, Bormuth, Coleman, Coleman.Liau, Dale.Chall,586
Danielson.Bryan, Dickes.Steiwer, DRP, ELF, Farr.Jenkins.Paterson, Flesch, Flesch.Kincaid, FOG,587
FORCAST, Fucks, Gutierrez, Harris.Jacobson, Linsear.Write, LIX, nWS, RIX, SMOG, Spache,588
Strain, Traenkle.Bailer, TRI, Tuldava, Wheeler.Smith), which are computed for every essay.589
• Grammatical and typographical errors:The number of grammatical and typographical errors590
in a text carries important information about the capabilities of the author which might be captured591
neither by the embeddings nor the proposed metrics. We therefore use the LanguageTool CLI via592
the LanguageToolR-package to get a list of more than 184,000 errors in total over all essays which593
we group into distinct categories like grammar, misspelling, typographical, duplication, and style.594
For each category, we then calculate error/word-ratios that are used as input to the SuperLearner.595
A.2 Teacher Assessments596
At age 11, teachers of the respondents were asked to assess their students:597
“In so far as your professional experience will allow, please rate the child in relation to all598
children of his age (i.e. not just his present class or even his school) by ringing the number599
opposite the appropriate description (going from 1 - Exceptional to 5 - Very limited.)”600
For our purposes, four questions are particularly relevant and are used in the analysis:601
• General knowledge602
• Number work603
• Use of books604
• Oral ability605
As a testament to the teachers’ calibration, all four variables exhibit behavior akin to a normal distri-606
bution, as can be seen in Figure D.5. We extend this selection by six additional items, this time less607
focused on the scholastic abilities of the child, but more on their behavior and motor abilities:608
“Below are a few descriptions of behavior shown by some children. Any one particular de-609
scription is likely to apply to only a minority of children; moreover, quite a proportion of610
children may show at least in some degree one of the aspects of behavior listed below. If the611
description fits the child, please circle the figure 1 in the first column. If it is a marginal case,612
or you are in some doubt about the child’s inclusion under this description, please circle the613
figure 2 in the next column. If the description does not fit the child at all circle the figure 3614
in the third column (going from 1 - Cert. applies to 3 - Not at all).”615
The list that was provided included the following behavioural descriptors:616
• Has poor hand control617
• Squirmy, fidgety618
• Has poor physical co-ordination619
• Hardly ever still620
• Has speech difficulties621
• Imperfect grasp of English622
However, most children are judged to exhibit none of the behaviors in question, as shown in Figure D.6.623
Finally, we utilize an additional set of behavior assessments at age 11 (Shepherd, 2013), in which a series624
of behavioral descriptions is given. The teacher is asked to underline the descriptions which best fit the625
child. By summing the number of selected items, a quantitative assessment of the child’s adjustment to626
school is obtained for multiple categories.627
• Inconsequential Behavior628
• Nervous Symptoms629
• Anxiety for Acceptance (Adults)630
• Anxiety for Acceptance (Children)631
• Hostility towards Children632
• Writing off Adults/Adult Standards633
• Hostility towards Adults634
• Miscellaneous Symptoms635
• Restlessness636
• Unforthcomingness637
• Depression638
• Withdrawal639
The maximum score differs for each category. However, most participants received the lowest possible640
assessment (Figure D.7).641
A.3 Genomic data642
Genetic data for the NCDS cohort were obtained from samples collected during the biomedical sweep643
conducted between 2002 and 2004. Genotyping was performed on these samples in separate batches using644
various genotyping chips, followed by independent imputation. The resulting genetic information was645
then integrated into a comprehensive genetic database, which includes data for 6,435 study participants.646
A portion of the samples were genotyped as control cases in the WTCCC1, WTCCC2, and T1DGC647
consortia. Comprehensive details regarding the quality control (QC) and imputation procedures applied648
to these samples can be found in the works of Soler Artigas et al. (2015) and Davies et al. (2015). In649
cases where samples were genotyped on multiple chips, preference was given to those that underwent650
imputation and QC by Soler Artigas et al. (2015). To maintain consistency, all samples were limited651
to SNPs in common with the reference panel of the 1,000 Genomes Project. The final sample consisted652
of 37,772,588 variants on 6,437 individuals. Using PRSice2 (Choi and O’Reilly, 2019), we then applied653
publicly available summary statistics of GWAS to construct polygenic scores for a set of 33 curated654
traits likely to show associations with the outcomes in question, listed in Table E.1. Polygenic scores655
were calculated using a prespecified threshold of p = 0.5 in the sample and with the software default values656
for clumping (250kb window; r2 = .1). To assess the robustness of our genetic prediction results, we657
conducted additional analyses using all polygenic scores made available by the Polygenic Index Repository658
(Becker et al., 2021). The Repository PGIs were created using summary statistics from large-scale659
genome-wide association studies (GWAS), including data from UK Biobank and 23andMe. The PGIs660
were constructed using Plink2 with SNP weights adjusted for linkage disequilibrium (LD) using LDpred, a661
method that has been shown to improve the predictive power of polygenic scores compared to traditional662
methods that do not account for LD. Results for a comparison of both sets of PGSs can be found in663
Figure D.1. The results were largely consistent with our primary findings, Although scores from the664
PGI-Repository provided slightly less accuracy.665
18
B Outcomes666
We seek to evaluate the extent to which genomic data, teacher assessments, and the information embed-667
ded in the essays are able to predict a range of outcome variables that can be broadly categorized under668
three different themes: Cognitive Ability, non-cognitive Traits and Socioeconomic Outcomes.669
B.1 Cognitive Ability670
An array of tests conducted at age 11 is used to operationalize competencies such as:671
• Verbal Ability,672
• Nonverbal Ability,673
• Reading Ability,674
• Mathematical Ability.675
The associated variables are given in Table E.6. We used these variables to create a measure of general676
cognitive ability by means of factor analysis. A 1-factor EFA was fitted using thepsych package (Revelle,677
2017). All items show high loadings on a general ability factor and together explain more than 75% of678
the variance. We extract the factor scores from this model as our measure of general intelligence. In679
addition, two tests of reading comprehension and mathematical ability at age 16 were used. A new680
reading comprehension test consisted of 35 multiple-choice questions where the child must select the681
appropriate word to complete a sentence, with scoring based on the number of correct answers. The682
mathematics test included both numerical and geometric questions with a combination of 27 categorical683
and four binary questions, scored in a similar manner.684
B.2 Non-Cognitive Traits685
Scholastic Motivation: Scholastic motivation was measured by a battery of self-assessed items in686
Sweep 3 (age 16) using a five-point Likert-scale expressing agreement with the following statements. The687
exact wording was:688
“Below is a list of things that people of your age have said about how they feel towards school.689
Read each one carefully and then ring one of the numbers to show for each one how true you690
think what it says is in your own case.”691
The associated variables are displayed in Table E.7. A one-factor solution once more fits the data well692
(53.7% variance explained). Note that we use polychoric correlations as we are analyzing Likert-scale693
data.694
695
Externalizing Behavior: A wide range of items at age 16 taken from the Rutter scale was used to696
construct measures of externalizing behavior (Table E.8). Each represents the answer on a scale from697
one (“Does not apply”) to three (“Certainly applies”) to the following prompt:698
“Below is a series of descriptions of behavior often shown by school children. Please ring699
the appropriate number in each case to show the degree to which the study child exhibits700
the behavior described. Please complete on the basis of the child’s behavior in the past 12701
months.”702
All items show high loadings on a single factor in an EFA with polychoric correlations whose results were703
used to generate factor scores of externalizing behavior.704
705
Internalizing Behaviour: A further subset of items (Table E.9) collected at age 16 was used to706
construct measures of internalizing behavior. Each one again represents the answer on a scale from one707
(“Does not apply”) to three (“Certainly applies”) to the prompt:708
“Below is a series of descriptions of behavior often shown by school children. Please ring709
the appropriate number in each case to show the degree to which the study child exhibits710
the behavior described. Please complete on the basis of the child’s behavior in the past 12711
months.”712
19
All items show high loadings on a single factor in an EFA with polychoric correlations whose results were713
used to generate factor scores of internalizing behavior.714
715
Occupational Aspirations: At age 16, cohort members were asked about the first job they aspired716
to have (variable name: n2771). The distribution is displayed in Figure D.8. These occupations were717
mapped to the 1970 Classification of Occupations (variable name: co70) which was the current statistical718
standard in 1974 when the cohort members were interviewed. Using the mapping to co70 provided by719
the CAMSIS-project (Lambert and Prandy, 2023), a measure of occupational status was then assigned720
to each occupation.5721
B.3 Educational Attainment722
A measure of the highest education obtained up to age 33 is available in Sweep 5 (variable name: hqual33)723
as a six-level outcome, ranging from ‘No qualification’ to ‘Degree/higher NVQ 5,6’. It was treated as an724
ordinal variable in all analyses.725
5Different occupations are mapped to different CAMSIS scores depending on whether the respondent is an employer,
employee, or self-employed. As this information was not available for the occupation in question, the score for employee
was used.

C Additional Analyses726
C.1 Incremental Utility of SuperLearner over OLS727
We investigated to what extent the utility of the SuperLearner-based ensemble of machine learning728
methods used in this study exceeds standard OLS regressions. For this purpose, we ran 10-fold cross-729
validated OLS regressions using our three sets of covariates (teacher assessments, essays, and genetic730
data) in order to predict cognitive and non-cognitive outcomes. We then computed the difference in731
R2
Holdout to the respective SuperLearner model. The comparison is plotted in Figure D.9. We note732
virtually identical results for teacher assessments and genetic data, and substantial improvements for733
the essay-based predictors. For multiple non-cognitive outcomes, OLS-based prediction substantially734
under-performs a simple model using only the mean of the dependent variable in the training sample,735
leading to negative R2
Holdout values. In these cases, the difference to zero was calculated.736
C.2 Predicting Personality at Age 50737
To extend the set of non-cognitive traits in our analysis, we also tested if essays, polygenic scores, and738
teacher evaluations were able to predict dimensions of personality. Unfortunately, the earliest measure739
of personality is available at age 50: The NCDS self-completion questionnaire in Sweep 8 contained740
50 questions from the International Personality Item Pool (IPIP, Goldberg et al., 2006), as shown in741
Table E.10. The answers can be summed to obtain scores for the ‘Big-5’ personality traits: extraversion,742
neuroticism, conscientiousness, agreeableness, and openness to experience. The scores for each trait743
range from 5 to 50, with higher scores corresponding to a higher expression of the respective trait. Even744
though our predictors are fixed at birth (genetic markers) or at age 11 (essays and teacher assessments)745
and the outcome is measured substantially later in life (educational attainment at age 33), the mean746
predictive R2 over all folds is greater than zero for all traits. This is highest for agreeableness and747
openness, where more than 10% of the variance can be explained by the essays (Figure D.10).748
C.3 Robustness of Results Regarding Sample Composition749
As our analyses depend on variables with different patterns of nonresponse, we use all available observa-750
tions in each of our models, leading to differences in sample composition that might influence results, as751
shown in Table E.11. To show that sample composition does not affect our findings, we reran our anal-752
ysis on the subset of individuals with full information on every variable used in the main text, meaning753
genotyped respondents with available essays, teacher assessments, (non-)cognitive information, highest754
education at age 33, parental education, height at age 11, sex, and birthweight. This final set consisted755
of only 1,618 individuals. Results are displayed in Figure D.11. In this case, variation in predictive per-756
formance over all cross-validation folds is much larger compared to our complete-case models, a sensible757
finding as each fold consists of fewer observations (and ‘learning error’ might not be fully eliminated).758
However, in all cases, the intervals denoting the range from worst to best prediction fold clearly overlap.759
The same holds true for our prediction of educational attainment, both for the stepwise prediction using760
combinations of teacher assessments, polygenic scores, and essays (Figure D.12), where the results of761
different folds clearly overlap.762
